--- title: "Data Objects in R" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: images/lake.jpg data-background-size: contain data-background-opacity: "0.5" subtitle: "STAT 220" author: "Bastola" format: revealjs: theme: [default, scss/main.scss] slide_level: 2 slide-number: true preview-links: auto history: true transition: slide background-transition: fade touch: false controls: true --- ## Object Oriented Programming in R
::: bql - R uses object-oriented programming (OOP) principles - Functions in R are designed to work with specific object classes and types - Example: `plot()` function behaves differently based on the input object ::: ## `plot()` Function Examples ::: bq Scatterplot with `plot()`: ::: {.cell} ::: :::
::: bq Diagnostic plots with `plot()`: ::: {.cell} ::: :::
The `plot()` function adapts its behavior based on the input object's class and type ## Data structures and types in R
::: bq - R objects are based on vectors - Two functions to examine objects: - `typeof()`: Returns the storage mode (data type) of an object - `class()`: Provides further description of an object - NULL: Represents an empty object (vector of length 0) ::: ## Examples of Data Types and Functions ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: eqt Numeric and integer data types: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "double" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: eqt Logical data type and class: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "logical" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "logical" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Atomic Vectors and lists ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"}
::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: bqt R uses two types of vectors to store info - **atomic vectors**: all entries have the same data type - **lists**: entries can contain other objects that can differ in data type ::: ::: ::: ## Examples of Vector Types ::: bq Atomic vector (numeric): ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "numeric" ``` ::: ::: :::
::: bq List with multiple data types: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "list" ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Atomic Vectors: Matrices ::: green-h You can add **attributes**, such as **dimension**, to vectors. A **matrix** is a 2-dimensional vector containing entries of the same type ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: font60 **Creating a matrix with dimensions:** ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "matrix" "array" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [,3] [1,] 1 4 7 [2,] 2 5 8 [3,] 3 6 9 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: font60 **Adding dimensions to a vector:** ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [,3] [1,] 1 3 5 [2,] 2 4 6 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "matrix" "array" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "double" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Creating Matrices Using Vector Binding ::: green-h Bind vectors of the same length to create columns or rows. Use `cbind()` for column binding and `rbind()` for row binding ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: font60 Column binding with `cbind()`: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x y [1,] 1 2 [2,] 2 4 [3,] 3 6 [4,] 4 8 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: font60 Row binding with `rbind()`: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] x1 1 2 3 4 x2 2 4 6 8 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Implicit and Explicit Coercion in R ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: bq ::: font80 Implicit Coercion - R defaults to the most complex data type if more than one type is given ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "1" "2" "a" "TRUE" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: bq ::: font80 Explicit coercion - Intentionally force a different data type from the "default" type ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "1" "2" "a" "TRUE" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Logical Vectors coercion ::: bq Logical values coerced into 0 for `FALSE` and 1 for `TRUE` when applying math functions ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 ``` ::: ::: Mean of a Logical Vector ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.25 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Examples: Coercion of Logical Values ::: bq Sum of Logical Values ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4 ``` ::: ::: :::
::: bq Mean of Logical Values ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.3333333 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Data types: factors Factors are a class of data that are stored as **integers** ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: bq ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "factor" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "no" "yes" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: bql ::: font60 The attribute `levels` is a character vector of possible values - Values are stored as the integers (1=first `level`, 2=second `level`, etc.) - Levels are ordered alphabetically/numerically (unless specified otherwise) ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Subsetting: Atomic Vector and Matrices ::: bq ::: font70 - subset with `[]` by referencing index value (from 1 to vector length): ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 8 2 1 3 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 3 2 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 8 1 ``` ::: ::: - subset with a logical vector ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 8 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Subsetting: Matrices ::: eqt Access entries using subsetting `[row,column]` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x y [1,] 1 2 [2,] 2 4 [3,] 3 6 [4,] 4 8 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 3 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Subsetting: Atomic Vector and Matrices ::: font90 ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: bq ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x double_x 1 8 16 2 2 4 3 1 2 4 3 6 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 8 2 1 3 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: bq or access columns with `$` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 8 2 1 3 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "numeric" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: middle-align-xy ## Tibbles ::: bq - are a new modern data frame - never changes the input data types - can have columns that are lists - can have non-standard variable names - can start with a number or contain spaces ::: ::: ## Subsetting data frames ::: bq - Can also use column names to subset: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 2 name sex 1 Mary F 2 Anna F ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Lists: Flexible Data Containers ::: lqt List is a vector with entries that can be different object types ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $myVec [1] 8 2 1 3 $myDf x double_x 1 8 16 2 2 4 3 1 2 4 3 6 $myString [1] "hi" "bye" ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Accessing List Elements ::: lqt Like a data frame, use the \$ to access named objects stored in the list ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x double_x 1 8 16 2 2 4 3 1 2 4 3 6 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "data.frame" ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Subsetting Lists with Single Brackets ::: bq - One `[]` operator gives you the object at the given location but preserves the list type - `my_list[2]` returns a list of length one with entry `myDf` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $myDf x double_x 1 8 16 2 2 4 3 1 2 4 3 6 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` List of 1 $ myDf:'data.frame': 4 obs. of 2 variables: ..$ x : num [1:4] 8 2 1 3 ..$ double_x: num [1:4] 16 4 2 6 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Subsetting Lists with Double Brackets ::: bq - The double `[[]]` operator gives you the object stored at that location (equivalent to using \$) - `my_list[[2]]` or `my_list[["myDf"]]` return the data frame `myDf` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x double_x 1 8 16 2 2 4 3 1 2 4 3 6 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: centered-content ##  Group Activity 1 {background="#ffdf9e"} ::: row ::: left ![](https://media.giphy.com/media/RKApDdwsQ6jkwd6RNn/giphy.gif) ::: ::: right ::: lqt - Please clone the `ca3-yourusername` repository from [Github](https://github.com/DataScienceSpring24) - Please do the problems on the class activity for today - Submit to Gradescope on [moodle](https://moodle.carleton.edu/course/view.php?id=43692) when done! ::: ::: ::: preservedd194c4af5da2f84 :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
